Extended Formulations for Order Polytopes
through Network Flows

Clintin P. Davis-Stober cstober2@gmail.com University of Missouri, Columbia. Jean-Paul Doignon111Corresponding author: Jean-Paul Doignon doignon@ulb.ac.be UniversitÃ© Libre de Bruxelles, Belgium Samuel Fiorini sfiorini@ulb.ac.be UniversitÃ© Libre de Bruxelles, Belgium. FranÃ§ois Glineur glineur@core.ucl.ac.be UniversitÃ© Catholique de Louvain, Belgium. Michel Regenwetter regenwet@uiuc.edu University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
Abstract

Mathematical psychology has a long tradition of modeling probabilistic choice via distribution-free random utility models and associated random preference models. For such models, the predicted choice probabilities often form a bounded and convex polyhedral set, or polytope. Polyhedral combinatorics have thus played a key role in studying the mathematical structure of these models. However, standard methods for characterizing the polytopes of such models are subject to a combinatorial explosion in complexity as the number of choice alternatives increases. Specifically, this is the case for random preference models based on linear, weak, semi- and interval orders. For these, a complete, linear description of the polytope is currently known only for, at most, 5â€“8 choice alternatives. We leverage the method of extended formulations to break through those boundaries. For each of the four types of preferences, we build an appropriate network, and show that the associated network flow polytope provides an extended formulation of the polytope of the choice model. This extended formulation has a simple linear description that is more parsimonious than descriptions obtained by standard methods for large numbers of choice alternatives. The result is a computationally less demanding way of testing the probabilistic choice model on data. We sketch how the latter interfaces with recent developments in contemporary statistics.

keywords:
Order Polytopes , Extended Formulations , Network Flows , Probabilistic Choice , Distribution Free Random Utility
MSC:
[2010] 06A07 , 52B12 , 91E99

1 Introduction

Much of the literature on choice behavior in the social sciences centers on modeling the unobservable hypothetical preferences or cognitive processes underlying observable choice behavior. This endeavor encounters a huge hurdle in empirical applications: How can models accommodate heterogeneity in choice behavior across individuals as well as within any given individual? To this end, researchers have employed a variety of probabilistic modeling approaches. Prominent examples include computational, stochastic process models that mimic hypothetical cognitive processes, such as the well-known diffusion model (e.g., Ratcliff & Smith, 2004, Ratcliff & Rouder, 1998) and the linear ballistic accumulator model (Brown & Heathcote, 2008, Trueblood etÂ al., 2014). Other approaches include multinomial processing tree models (see, e.g., Erdfelder etÂ al., 2009, for a review). Rather than model latent cognitive processes, we concentrate on the more abstract notion of latent preferences. In so doing, we consider models that use a minimum of mathematical assumptions and that delineate large classes of theories of choice behavior. This approach is grounded in a long tradition of axiomatization and axiom testing in mathematical psychology (see, e.g., Luce, 2000) and naturally interfaces with contemporary statistical methods (Davis-Stober & Brown, 2011, Davis-Stober etÂ al., 2015). Evaluating choice data against such models allows for strong inferences regarding the latent preferences that give rise to choice behavior. Here, we tackle challenges with the mathematical characterization of such models.

Specifically, we consider classes of choice theories based upon four types of transitive binary preference relations: linear orders (rankings without ties), weak orders (rankings with or without ties), semiorders (partial rankings up to a constant threshold of discrimination), and interval orders (partial rankings up to a stimulus-dependent threshold of discrimination). For each of these algebraic representations of preferences, we consider probabilistic choice induced by an (unspecified) probability distribution over permissible preference states, i.e., over relations of the selected type. These models are also known in the literature as random preference models, mixture models, or random relation models. Because each of these models has been shown to have a random utility representation, our results also directly apply to characterizing various kinds of distribution-free random utility models, as well as random function models (see, e.g., Regenwetter & Marley, 2001).

Among the most important applications of these models are studies aimed at testing whether decision makers have transitive preferences (e.g., because they employ compensatory decision strategies by which they coherently trade-off between competing decision attributes) or whether they violate transitivity (say, because they employ simple heuristics that cause â€˜incoherentâ€™ preferences). It is well-known (Roberts, 1979) that, for finitely many choice options, complete asymmetric binary preferences are transitive if and only if they are strict linear orders. Dropping the requirement of complete preference, asymmetric binary preferences on a finite set of choice options are negatively transitive (hence also transitive) if and only if they are strict weak orders (Roberts, 1979). Testing random preference models on laboratory data faces two main hurdles: i)Â Because the model ranges of these models form convex polytopes (that is, bounded convex polyhedral sets as in Ziegler 1998), they require order-constrained statistical methods; ii)Â The order constraints (geometrically, the linear inequalities defining facets of the polytope) are fully known only when the number of choice alternatives is small. Recent developments have essentially solved the first challenge (see Davis-Stober, 2009, Karabatsos, 2006, Klugkist & Hoijtink, 2007, Myung etÂ al., 2005, Silvapulle & Sen, 2005).

Using some of these approaches, Regenwetter etÂ al. (2011a) provided the first empirical and statistically adequate test of the â€œlinear ordering modelâ€ in the literature. Following Tversky (1969), they used five choice alternatives per stimulus set. Regenwetter & Davis-Stober (2012), who reported the first empirical test of the â€œweak order model,â€ also used five choice alternatives per stimulus set, in this case because the mathematical structure of the weak order polytope is not yet fully understood for larger numbers of choice alternatives. Regenwetter & Davis-Stober (2011) used four choice alternatives to test the â€œsemiorder modelâ€ and the â€œinterval order modelâ€ because they did not know a full description of the corresponding polytopes for more than four options.

In this article, we leverage extended formulations. We study network flow polytopes to characterize random preference models of linear, weak, semi-, and interval orders in novel ways. This approach generates a simpler, more parsimonious description of the corresponding random preference model and allows empirical researchers to study these models for larger numbers of choice alternatives than previously possible.

The paper proceeds as follows. First, we review key facts about linear, weak, semi-, and interval orders. Then, we discuss the convex polytopes associated with the random preference models based on each of these four types of preference relations and the obstacles faced by traditional mathematical methods for characterizing their model ranges. The following two sections overcome these obstacles and investigate extended formulations, especially those based on network flows, and associated network flow polytopes. We then discuss how these network flow polytopes interface with some contemporary developments in statistics. We end with a summary and detail future directions of this work.

2 Models of Pairwise Preferences and their Numerical Representations

Throughout the paper, Sğ‘†S denotes a finite set of nğ‘›n choice alternatives (thus, |S|=nğ‘†ğ‘›|S|=n). The preferences of a decision maker among the alternatives are cast as a relation Rğ‘…R on Sğ‘†S, with iâ€‹Râ€‹jğ‘–ğ‘…ğ‘—i\,R\,j meaning that the decision maker likes iğ‘–i strictly less than jğ‘—j (hence strictly prefers jğ‘—j over iğ‘–i). In a simple case, the relation Rğ‘…R is a linear order, that is an irreflexive, transitive and complete relation (for a definition of these and similar terms, see for instance Fishburn 1985, ChapterÂ 1, or Pirlot & Vincke 1997, ChapterÂ 3). As is well-known, such an ideal situation occurs when preferences reflect comparisons of utility values and no two choice alternatives have the same utility.

Proposition 1 (Linear order).

The relation Rğ‘…R on the set Sğ‘†S of alternatives is a linear order if and only if there exists an injective mapping u:Sâ†’â„:ğ‘¢â†’ğ‘†â„u:\;S\to\mathbb{R} such that, for all iğ‘–i, jğ‘—j in Sğ‘†S:

Proposition 2 (Weak order).

3 Random Preference Models and their Associated Polytopes

Relations like those of PropositionsÂ 1â€“4 can be used to model the decision makerâ€™s preferences at a particular moment. In general, the decision maker may be uncertain about her preferences and may probabilistically sample a preference from some collection of preference states, when required to make decisions. We assume all permissible preference states obey the model selected. Thus, at any time we may interview the decision maker about any pair (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) of alternatives, and collect an answer reflecting her currently sampled preference. As a consequence, repeated interviews will lead to frequencies of having iâ€‹Râ€‹jğ‘–ğ‘…ğ‘—i\,R\,j (or not). A classical result (see, for instance, Ziegler 1998) states that any polytope admits a linear description, that is a finite system of linear equations and inequalities whose solution set is exactly the polytope. Even if we insist that the system has a minimum number of equations and inequalities, it is generally not unique; however, the number of linear equations is then the codimension of the polytope, and there is exactly one inequality per facet of the polytope. In the case of the linear order polytope PLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, the number of equations on â„Sâ‹†Ssuperscriptâ„â‹†ğ‘†ğ‘†\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} equals (n2)=nâ€‹(nâˆ’1)/2binomialğ‘›2ğ‘›ğ‘›12\binom{n}{2}=n(n-1)/2 (those being the already mentioned p(i,j)+p(j,i)=1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–1p_{(i,j)}+p_{(j,i)}=1), but no precise estimation seems to be available on the number of inequalities. For n=8ğ‘›8n=8, the number of vertices is 8!=40,3208403208!=40{,}320 but only a lower bound on the number of facets is available. This lower bound is huge: the polytope has at least 488,602,996488602996488{,}602{,}996 facets (Christof & Reinelt, 1996). Two other polytopes play a role in our study. They are the interval order polytope of Sğ‘†S

The interval order polytope is investigated by MÃ¼ller & Schulz (1995), the semiorder polytope by Suck (1995) and both of them by Doignon & Rexhep (2016). For n=4ğ‘›4n=4, Regenwetter & Davis-Stober (2011) reports that the interval order polytope has 207207207 vertices and 191191191 facets, while the figures for the semiorder polytope are 183183183 and 563563563.

4 Network Flow Representations of Order Polytopes

We now move to a third way of investigating our four order polytopes. Many applications in psychology and economics aim to evaluate random preference models on human subjects choice data from laboratory studies. This typically involves optimizing concave functions (e.g., a log-likelihood function) subject to the constraint that the choice probabilities belong to the polytope in question. Such optimizations are straightforward when the geometric structure of the polytope is fully known. The extended formulations that we now consider make it possible to solve some of these optimization goals in cases where obtaining a complete geometric representation of the polytope in question is computationally expensive.

4.1 The concept of an extended formulation

In the previous section, we described how testing whether a collection of choice probabilities satisfies the linear order model amounts to checking whether a given point lies in the linear order polytope PLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S} (we again base our exposition on this model), which can be done by checking the validity of each linear equation and inequality in its description). Unfortunately, unless we limit ourselves to small enough nğ‘›n the latter task is made difficult or even impossible by the inherent intricacy, or sheer unavailability, of a linear description of PLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}. In this section, we sketch the main steps to overcome this difficulty. We provide technical constructions and proofs in the next section.

The main idea is to work with another, ad hoc polytope that projects in some specific way on PLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S} (more precisely: there is an affine transformation mapping the ad hoc polytope onto PLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}). Any linear description of such an ad hoc polytope is called an extended formulation of PLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}. For a survey of the notion of an extended formulation, see Conforti etÂ al. (2010), Kaibel (2011) and Wolsey (2011). For the four order polytopes we study in this paper, the ad hoc polytope happens to be a â€œflow polytopeâ€, so we first define the latter notion and review some known facts.

4.2 The concept of a network flow polytope

Let D=(N,A)ğ·ğ‘ğ´D=(N,A) be a network with node set Nğ‘N and arc set Ağ´A (for network terminology, see, for instance, Korte & Vygen, 2008). In Nğ‘N, we designate two special nodes: the source node sğ‘ s and the sink node tğ‘¡t.

For a node vğ‘£v, we denote the sets of arcs leaving and entering vğ‘£v by Î´+â€‹(v)superscriptğ›¿ğ‘£\delta^{+}(v) and Î´âˆ’â€‹(v)superscriptğ›¿ğ‘£\delta^{-}(v), respectively. Formally,

Following the current practice in extended formulations, we define the size of a linear description as the total number of inequalities in the description, thus disregarding the number of variables and equalities, as well as the bit complexity of the coefficients. Again, let Sğ‘†S denote the set of alternatives, with |S|=nğ‘†ğ‘›|S|=n. We explicitly build this flow polytope, which is thus an extended formulation. We also build a flow polytope providing an extended formulation for the semiorder polytope with, surprisingly, canonical description size in Î©â€‹(n!)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n!), which is not Oâ€‹(cn)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘ğ‘›O(c^{n}) for any constant cğ‘c.

As we discuss later in SectionÂ 7, it follows from recent results that all our extended formulations are size-optimal, except perhaps that for the semiorder polytope. More precisely, any extended formulation for any of our order polytopes for a set of alternatives of size nğ‘›n has size at least (3/2)âŒŠn/2âŒ‹superscript32ğ‘›2(3/2)^{\lfloor n/2\rfloor}.

In order to specify the networks, the key idea is to use ordinal representations of the relations involved. We start with weak orders.

4.4 The case of linear orders

We now turn to the linear orders on Sğ‘†S. In the above network (for weak orders), they correspond to the sğ‘ sâ€“tğ‘¡t paths that use only arcs (X,Z)ğ‘‹ğ‘(X,Z) where XâŠ‚Zğ‘‹ğ‘X\subset Z with the restriction that |X|+1=|Z|ğ‘‹1ğ‘|X|+1=|Z|. Because the sğ‘ sâ€“tğ‘¡t paths describing linear orders only use those arcs, we now delete all the other arcs from the network while keeping all the nodes. In the resulting network, the sğ‘ sâ€“tğ‘¡t paths bijectively correspond to the linear orders on Sğ‘†S. We later infer a projection from the flow polytope of this network to the linear order polytope of Sğ‘†S (see TheoremÂ 1).

4.6 The case of semiorders

The case of semiorders is a bit more involved. Semiorders are particular interval orders, so they correspond to profiles of interval orders having an additional property. We would like to build a new network whose sğ‘ sâ€“tğ‘¡t paths exactly correspond to the profiles of semiorders. We obtain the nodes of the new network similarly as those of DLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·LOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, but we store more information at each node. The crucial property on which we rely is well known (see for instance Bogart & West, 1999): an interval order is a semiorder if and only if it admits a representation by intervals such that no interval contains another interval unless they share an endpoint. We now state this property formally.

Proposition 5.

A relation Rğ‘…R on the set Sğ‘†S is a semiorder if and only if there exist two mappings â„“,h:Sâ†’â„:â„“â„â†’ğ‘†â„\ell,h:\;S\to\mathbb{R} such that, for all iğ‘–i, jğ‘—j in Sğ‘†S:

â„“â€‹(i)â‰¤hâ€‹(i);â„“ğ‘–â„ğ‘–\displaystyle\ell(i)\leq h(i); (23)
iâ€‹Râ€‹jâ‡”hâ€‹(i)<â„“â€‹(j);iffğ‘–ğ‘…ğ‘—â„ğ‘–â„“ğ‘—\displaystyle i\,R\,j\;\iff\;h(i)<\ell(j); (24)
â„“â€‹(i)<â„“â€‹(j)âŸ¹hâ€‹(i)â‰¤hâ€‹(j).â„“ğ‘–â„“ğ‘—â„ğ‘–â„ğ‘—\displaystyle\ell(i)<\ell(j)\implies h(i)\leq h(j). (25)

PropositionÂ 5 can be easily deduced from PropositionÂ 4 (direct proofs also exist, see for instance Bogart & West 1999).

The network we build for semiorders has as nodes all triples (X,Y,L)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ¿(X,Y,L) with YâŠ†XâŠ†Sğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘†Y\subseteq X\subseteq S and with Lğ¿L a linear order on Xâˆ–Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX\setminus Y. To motivate the later specification of arcs, we show how each representation of a specific type of a semiorder generates a sequence of nodes that eventually becomes an sğ‘ sâ€“tğ‘¡t path. Given a representation â„“â„“\ell, hâ„h as in PropositionÂ 5 for a semiorder Rğ‘…R, first adjust the values of â„“â„“\ell, hâ„h to get a representation where â„“â„“\ell, hâ„h are one-to-one and where â„“â€‹(S)âˆ©hâ€‹(S)=âˆ…â„“ğ‘†â„ğ‘†\ell(S)\cap h(S)=\varnothing. An illustration is given in FigureÂ 2. Varying the value of Ï„ğœ\tau, we thus generate a sequence of distinct nodes. We later specify the arcs so that each such sequence becomes an sğ‘ sâ€“tğ‘¡t path, and each sğ‘ sâ€“tğ‘¡t path is such a sequence. Furthermore, the resulting flow polytope provides an extended formulation of the semiorder polytope. The details are provided in SubsectionÂ 5.4. In particular, we show that the canonical description of this flow polytope grows faster in size than the extended formulations of our three other order polytopes. In the case of the semiorder polytope, we get an extended formulation of size 2Î˜â€‹(nâ€‹logâ¡n)superscript2Î˜ğ‘›ğ‘›2^{\Theta(n\log n)}, while for the other order polytopes, we obtain extended formulations of size 2Î˜â€‹(n)superscript2Î˜ğ‘›2^{\Theta(n)}.

5 Customizing Extended Formulations as Network Flow Polytopes

In the next four subsections, we give detailed constructions and proofs of the results announced in SectionÂ 4.

5.1 The case of the linear order polytope

Theorem 3.

Let Ï€ğœ‹\pi be the projection from â„Asuperscriptâ„ğ´\mathbb{R}^{A} to â„Sâ‹†Ssuperscriptâ„â‹†ğ‘†ğ‘†\mathbb{R}^{S\star S}, mapping a point Î¦âˆˆâ„AÎ¦superscriptâ„ğ´\Phi\in\mathbb{R}^{A} to the point xâˆˆâ„Sâ‹†Sğ‘¥superscriptâ„â‹†ğ‘†ğ‘†x\in\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} given, for all (i,j)âˆˆSâ‹†Sğ‘–ğ‘—â‹†ğ‘†ğ‘†(i,j)\in S\star S, by

Then Ï€ğœ‹\pi maps the flow polytope of DIOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·IOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S} onto the interval order polytope of Sğ‘†S. Proof.

The structure of the proof is similar to that of Theorem 1 (see however RemarkÂ 3 below). We show that the image of the vertex set of Fâ€‹(DIOS)ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·IOğ‘†F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) under the projection Ï€ğœ‹\pi is exactly the vertex set of PIâ€‹OSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ¼ğ‘‚ğ‘†P_{IO}^{S}.

Consider a vertex v=xRğ‘£superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘…v=x^{R} of PIâ€‹OSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ¼ğ‘‚ğ‘†P_{IO}^{S} and a vertex Î¦=Ï‡Aâ€‹(P)Î¦superscriptğœ’ğ´ğ‘ƒ\Phi=\chi^{A(P)} of Fâ€‹(DIOS)ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·IOğ‘†F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) such that Î¦Î¦\Phi encodes the profile of some ordinal representation of the interval order Rğ‘…R, say by injective mappings â„“â„“\ell and hâ„h from Sğ‘†S to â„â„\mathbb{R} with â„“â€‹(S)âˆ©hâ€‹(S)=âˆ…â„“ğ‘†â„ğ‘†\ell(S)\cap h(S)=\varnothing. Let iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j be two distinct alternatives of Sğ‘†S. The right-hand side of (26) must give Z=X+{j}ğ‘ğ‘‹ğ‘—Z=X+\{j\} and Y=Tğ‘Œğ‘‡Y=T (by the definition of the arcs in Ağ´A). Remark 3.

In the proofs of TheoremÂ 1 and 2, the projection of the flow polytope on the order polytope induces a bijective mapping between the vertex sets of the two polytopes. This is not the case here: in general, several vertices of the flow polytope are mapped onto the same vertex of PIâ€‹OSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ¼ğ‘‚ğ‘†P_{IO}^{S}. The reason is that different representations of the same interval order can lead to distinct profiles, and thus to different paths in the network.

Remark 4.

Recall that, for n=4ğ‘›4n=4, the interval order polytope has 191191191 facets. This is less than the size of the canonical description of the flow polytope Fâ€‹(DIOS)ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·IOğ‘†F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) with |S|=4ğ‘†4|S|=4, which is 216216216. For larger values of nğ‘›n, we do not know the exact number of facets of the interval order polytope. However, a lower bound on this number follows from Doignon & Rexhep (2016, TheoremÂ 8 and CorollaryÂ 1): the interval order polytope Fâ€‹(DIOS)ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·IOğ‘†F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) has at least as many facets as there are â€˜PC-graphsâ€™ on Sğ‘†S, where a PC-graph is a directed graph in which any node is the tail of at most one arc, and the head of at most one arc (in other words, a PC-graph is a node-disjoint union of paths and cycles plus maybe isolated nodes). For small numbers of alternatives, we provide in TableÂ 1 both the resulting lower bound on the size of any linear description of the interval order polytope PIâ€‹Onsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ¼ğ‘‚ğ‘›P_{IO}^{n}, and the exact size of the canonical description of the flow polytope Fâ€‹(DIOS)ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·IOğ‘†F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}). The flow polytope definitely has a smaller description size for n=6ğ‘›6n=6 (the same could hold for n=5ğ‘›5n=5). It is not difficult to see that the same assertion holds for nâ‰¥7ğ‘›7n\geq 7.

5.4 The case of the semiorder polytope

The network DSOS=(N,A)superscriptsubscriptğ·SOğ‘†ğ‘ğ´D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}=(N,A) we build for the semiorder polytope of Sğ‘†S is more structured than the one for the interval order polytope of Sğ‘†S. Remark 5.

Recall that, for n=4ğ‘›4n=4, the semiorder polytope has 563563563 facets. However we can prove that there exists a natural number n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} such that, for all n>n0ğ‘›subscriptğ‘›0n>n_{0}, the description size of the flow polytope Fâ€‹(DSOS)ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·SOğ‘†F(D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}) will be smaller than the number of facets of the polytope PSOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒSOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}. This is due to the fact that there are more facet defining inequalities for PSOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒSOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{n} than PC-graphs on nğ‘›n elements (Doignon & Rexhep, 2016, SectionÂ 9), and more PC-graphs than chain gangs, the latter being the disjoint unions of paths plus maybe isolated nodes. 6 Interface between Flow Polytopes and Statistics

In this section, we briefly consider how our network flow polytopes interface with contemporary statistical methods for evaluating random preference models. Typical choice data used in evaluating random preference models are comprised of decision maker responses to a series of repeated paired presentations of choice alternatives (see Regenwetter etÂ al., 2011a). We consider the case when pairs of options are offered and the decision maker must choose one (two-alternatives forced choice) or must either choose one or indicate indifference (ternary paired comparisons). Let p(i,j)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—p_{(i,j)} and C(i,j)subscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘—C_{(i,j)} denote the probability and the number of times that a decision maker chooses alternative jğ‘—j when offered alternatives iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j. Let ğ’‘:=(p(i,j))(i,j)âˆˆSâ‹†Sassignğ’‘subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—â‹†ğ‘†ğ‘†\boldsymbol{p}:=\left(p_{(i,j)}\right)_{(i,j)\in S\star S} and let ğ‘ª:=(C(i,j))(i,j)âˆˆSâ‹†Sassignğ‘ªsubscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—â‹†ğ‘†ğ‘†\boldsymbol{C}:=\left(C_{(i,j)}\right)_{(i,j)\in S\star S}. Let Lâ€‹(ğ’‘|ğ‘ª)ğ¿conditionalğ’‘ğ‘ªL(\boldsymbol{p}|\boldsymbol{C}) denote the likelihood of any given data ğ‘ªğ‘ª\boldsymbol{C} as a function of probabilities ğ’‘ğ’‘\boldsymbol{p}, (for examples involving multinomial distributions see e.g., Davis-Stober, 2009, Myung etÂ al., 2005, Regenwetter etÂ al., 2011a). In general, in a random preference model, the maximum likelihood estimate does not have a closed form solution and therefore requires convex optimization. The maximum likelihood estimate (MLE) for a given random preference model Pâ„³Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒâ„³ğ‘†P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} that is one of PLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, PWOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒWOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}, PSOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒSOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}, or PIOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒIOğ‘†P_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}, given choice data ğ‘ªğ‘ª\boldsymbol{C}, equals

ğ’‘^ğ“œğ‘ª:=argmaxğ’‘âˆˆPâ„³SLâ€‹(ğ’‘|ğ‘ª).assignsuperscriptsubscript^ğ’‘ğ“œğ‘ªsubscriptargmaxğ’‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒâ„³ğ‘†ğ¿conditionalğ’‘ğ‘ª\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{M}}}^{\boldsymbol{C}}:=\operatornamewithlimits{argmax}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S}}L(\boldsymbol{p}|\boldsymbol{C}). (38)

In a network flow representation, the MLE for Pâ„³Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒâ„³ğ‘†P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} can be calculated via the following optimization program:

(MLE-CP)minğ’‘âˆˆâ„Sâ‹†S,Î¦âˆˆâ„|A|âˆ’lnâ¡Lâ€‹(ğ’‘|ğ‘ª)s.t.Î¦âˆˆFâ€‹(Dâ„³S)ğ’‘=Ï€â€‹(Î¦),(MLE-CP)subscriptformulae-sequenceğ’‘superscriptâ„â‹†ğ‘†ğ‘†Î¦superscriptâ„ğ´ğ¿conditionalğ’‘ğ‘ªmissing-subexpressions.t.Î¦ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·â„³ğ‘†missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionğ’‘ğœ‹Î¦\begin{array}[]{rrl}\textrm{(MLE-CP)}&\min_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\mathbb{R}^{S\star S},\Phi\in\mathbb{R}^{|A|}}&-\ln L(\boldsymbol{p}|\boldsymbol{C})\\ &\textrm{s.t.}&\Phi\in F(D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S})\\ &&\boldsymbol{p}=\pi(\Phi),\end{array} (39)

where Dâ„³Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ·â„³ğ‘†D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} is one of DLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·LOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, DWOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·WOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}, DSOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·SOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}, or DIOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·IOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}, accordingly. This is a convex optimization problem because we minimize the opposite of the log-likelihood function, assumed to be convex, over a convex feasible region. Indeed, the two vectors of variables ğ’‘ğ’‘\boldsymbol{p} and ğš½ğš½\boldsymbol{\Phi} are only constrained by linear equations and inequalities, coming both from the canonical description (16) of the flow polytope Fâ€‹(Dâ„³S)ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·â„³ğ‘†F(D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S}) and the expression that ğ’‘ğ’‘\boldsymbol{p} is the projection of ğš½ğš½\boldsymbol{\Phi} by Ï€ğœ‹\pi (i.e. its image by an affine mapping).

The solution of this convex program yields the MLE as well as the maximized likelihood value. This convex program can be solved computationally by standard methods in convex optimization such as polynomial-time interior-point methods, see Nesterov & Nemirovskii (1994). Alternatively, the vector of variables ğ’‘ğ’‘\boldsymbol{p} can be eliminated from the formulation using the projection equalities, leading to

(MLE-CPâ€™)minÎ¦âˆˆâ„|A|âˆ’lnâ¡Lâ€‹(Ï€â€‹(Î¦)|ğ‘ª)s.t.Î¦âˆˆFâ€‹(Dâ„³S).(MLE-CPâ€™)subscriptÎ¦superscriptâ„ğ´ğ¿conditionalğœ‹Î¦ğ‘ªmissing-subexpressions.t.Î¦ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·â„³ğ‘†\begin{array}[]{rrl}\textrm{(MLE-CP')}&\min_{\Phi\in\mathbb{R}^{|A|}}&-\ln L(\pi(\Phi)|\boldsymbol{C})\\ &\textrm{s.t.}&\Phi\in F(D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S}).\end{array} (40)

This is now a convex nonlinear network optimization problem, see e.g.Â Bertsekas (1998) (note that while the objective function remains convex, it is no longer separable).

The maximum likelihood estimate ğ’‘^ğ“œğ‘ªsuperscriptsubscript^ğ’‘ğ“œğ‘ª\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{M}}}^{\boldsymbol{C}} is obtained by projecting the optimum flow Î¦^^Î¦\hat{\Phi} (which is not necessarily unique).

The Bayes factor is a standard method for assessing the relative empirical evidence for/against either of two competing models. It is defined as the ratio of their respective marginal likelihoods (Kass & Raftery, 1995). Following previous approaches in testing random preference models (Davis-Stober etÂ al., 2015), we compare the model Pâ„³Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒâ„³ğ‘†P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} to an â€œencompassingâ€ model that places no restrictions on choice probabilities. Assuming suitably chosen prior distributions, the Bayes factor can be re-written as the ratio of two proportions: the proportion of the encompassing prior in agreement with Pâ„³Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒâ„³ğ‘†P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} and the proportion of the encompassing posterior in agreement with Pâ„³Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒâ„³ğ‘†P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} (see Klugkist & Hoijtink, 2007). We estimate these proportions by repeatedly drawing from the prior and posterior distributions and counting the samples that satisfy Pâ„³Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒâ„³ğ‘†P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S}. Checking whether or not a sampled value of ğ’‘ğ’‘\boldsymbol{p} satisfies a given random preference model, using the extended formulation via a network flow, reduces to solving the following convex optimization program:

(Bayes-CP)minâ€–ğ’‘âˆ’ğ’‘sâ€–s.t.Î¦âˆˆFâ€‹(Dâ„³S)ğ’‘=Ï€â€‹(Î¦),(Bayes-CP)normğ’‘subscriptğ’‘ğ‘ missing-subexpressions.t.Î¦ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ·â„³ğ‘†missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionğ’‘ğœ‹Î¦\begin{array}[]{rrl}\textrm{(Bayes-CP)}&\min&\|\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}_{s}\|\\ &\textrm{s.t.}&\Phi\in F(D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S})\\ &&\boldsymbol{p}=\pi(\Phi),\end{array} (41)

where Dâ„³Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ·â„³ğ‘†D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} is one of DLOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·LOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, DWOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·WOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}, DSOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·SOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}, or DIOSsuperscriptsubscriptğ·IOğ‘†D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}, which can be solved in the same ways as (MLE-CP). If the optimal value of ğ’‘ğ’‘\boldsymbol{p} equals ğ’‘ssubscriptğ’‘ğ‘ \boldsymbol{p}_{s} then the sampled point lies inside the model, otherwise it does not. See Davis-Stober etÂ al. (2015) for additional details on using sampling methods to calculate Bayes factors under the weak order polytope.

7 Optimality

Here we discuss the asymptotic optimality of our extended formulations in terms of size. It will be convenient to use the notion of extension complexity of a polytope Pğ‘ƒP, defined as the minimum size of an extended formulation of Pğ‘ƒP. Notice that the extension complexity is affinely invariant, that is, two affinely equivalent polytopes Pğ‘ƒP and Qğ‘„Q have the same extension complexity, and that it is monotone in the sense that the extension complexity of a polytope Pğ‘ƒP is at least that of any of its faces Fğ¹F.

Maksimenko (2017) recently proved that the correlation polytope

PCORn:=conv{xâ€‹xâŠºâˆ£xâˆˆ{0,1}n}assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒCORğ‘›convconditional-setğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥âŠºğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘›P_{\mathrm{COR}}^{n}:=\mathop{\mathrm{conv}}\{xx^{\intercal}\mid x\in\{0,1\}^{n}\} (42)

is affinely equivalent to a face of the linear ordering polytope PLO2â€‹nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLO2ğ‘›P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{2n} (the linear ordering polytope for a set of 2â€‹n2ğ‘›2n alternatives). This implies that the extension complexity of PLO2â€‹nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLO2ğ‘›P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{2n} is at least that of PCORnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒCORğ‘›P_{\mathrm{COR}}^{n}, which in turn was proved to be at least (3/2)nsuperscript32ğ‘›(3/2)^{n}, see Fiorini etÂ al. (2015) and Kaibel & Weltge (2014). Therefore, the extension complexity of PLOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{n} is at least (3/2)âŒŠn/2âŒ‹superscript32ğ‘›2(3/2)^{\lfloor n/2\rfloor}. Moreover, since PWOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒWOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{n}, PIOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒIOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{IO}}^{n} and PSOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒSOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{n} all have PLOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{n} as a face, we see that their extension complexities are at least that of PLOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{n}. Since the extended formulations constructed in this paper for PLOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒLOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{n}, PWOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒWOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{n} and PIOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒIOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{IO}}^{n} have size 2Î˜â€‹(n)superscript2Î˜ğ‘›2^{\Theta(n)}, this implies that the three corresponding extension complexities are also 2Î˜â€‹(n)superscript2Î˜ğ‘›2^{\Theta(n)}, i.e.Â that these extended formulations are asymptotically optimal.

For the semiorder polytope, we only know that the extension complexity of PSOnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒSOğ‘›P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{n} is 2Î©â€‹(n)superscript2Î©ğ‘›2^{\Omega(n)} and at the same time 2Oâ€‹(nâ€‹logâ¡n)superscript2ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›2^{O(n\log n)}. We remark that it is possible that the semiorder polytope admits an extended formulation with size 2Î˜â€‹(n)superscript2Î˜ğ‘›2^{\Theta(n)} but no such extended formulation based on flows. Indeed, flow-based extended formulations are known to have strong limitations, seeÂ Fiorini & Pashkovich (2015).

8 Conclusions and Discussion

In this paper, we leverage extended formulations and network flow polytopes to work with random preference models for linear orders, weak orders, semiorders, and interval orders. Our results break through previous barriers in the number of choice alternatives for which parsimonious linear descriptions are known. One fundamental reason is that we provide a complete, linear description of the extended formulation (a polytope which projects on the polytope of choice probabilities permitted by the model). A second reason is that in many cases the extended formulation description is of smaller size than that of the initial polytope. However, in the case of semiorders, the extended formulation relies more heavily on the numerical representations of the relations and consequently entails an excessively large description. One interesting open question is to find a more parsimonious extended formulation in the case of semiorders, or prove that none exists.

A natural application of the extended formulations we have described is to expand empirical studies of fundamental structures (e.g., weakly ordered preferences) for larger numbers of choice alternatives than previously possible (Regenwetter & Davis-Stober, 2012). We leave this for future work.
